caption: This place is incredible and has an incredible collection of art. The collection of Claude Monet is located downstairs, and you can easily spend an hour or two exploring the stories of and behind each art piece. I would highly recommend listening to the audio guide they offer. The stories are well presented and very detailed. The place is not the best option for kids and would be recommended to families with an interest in art and history. And be ware - many stairs are waiting for you.

Lovely building in a lovely neighbourhood. Nice collection of paintings but many are missing. Asking about them I was told that they were borrowed. In this case I am not sure if the entry price is justified. Still, a nice experience.

If you’re a fan of Monet or Impressionism in general, Musée Marmottan Monet in Paris is an absolute must-visit. It’s a bit of a hidden gem compared to the larger museums, and that’s part of its charm.  Housed in what feels like a Parisian maison rather than a typical museum, the space is warm and intimate—like stepping into someone’s beautifully curated home rather than a grand, impersonal gallery. The interior design is elegant, with wood-paneled rooms, chandeliers, and rich, cozy colors that make the experience feel personal and immersive.  And then, of course, there’s the Monet collection. It’s breathtaking. The museum holds the largest collection of his works, including the famous Impression, Sunrise—the painting that literally gave Impressionism its name. The water lilies, the Japanese bridge, the Normandy landscapes—they’re all here, and up close, they feel even more alive.  One of my favorite things about this place is how it allows you to follow Monet’s artistic evolution. You see his earlier, more detailed works and then his later, almost abstract brushstrokes that dissolve into color and light. It’s like watching a master let go of form and embrace pure emotion.  The museum also has pieces from other Impressionist and Post-Impressionist artists, but Monet is the star. And because it’s slightly off the beaten path, it doesn’t have the overwhelming crowds of the Orsay or the Louvre. You can actually take your time, breathe, and just be with the art—which feels like the way Monet himself would have wanted it.  If you love Monet, or just want a museum that feels special and a little more personal, Musée Marmottan Monet is a perfect choice.

An excellent and very well-laid-out museum showcasing the art and furniture collection of the Marmottans. You get to see beautiful pieces of furniture,  mantlepiece clocks and gorgeous works of art by Monet, Renoir and other less-known artists but super talented nonetheless. The temporary exhibition of Trompe- L'œil had some interesting pieces, but it was very crowded to fully enjoy.

Underwhelmed but glad to have visited just the once. It took ages to get in. One person issuing tickets. I walked round the place and found zero directions to the Monet collection. There was absolutely no signage. I had to find somewhere to sit - not easy- and study the map and found the unlabelled staircase in the shop to the basement. The back entrance was at the end of the temporary exhibition. I had forgotten my water bottle so was desperate for a drink but they didn’t even have a water refill station. Not impressed.

A private mansion turned into an art gallery is home to the world's largest collection of works by Claude Monet. I went mid week and there was not waiting. I was able to get right in and it was not crowded at all.

A must visit for Monet fans.  My wife ended up purchasing a customized book with works she selected using an app by scanning labels, but the app was difficult for her to use ended up to be a distraction from enjoying the art.  I would recommend against this app.  We did not buy our tickets in advance on a weekend and did not end up needing to wait long for entry.

Fantastic experience. The ability to get so up close and personal with the paintings is rare. Some other reviews mentioned the app not working well but for me it was flawless. The book you can order has the ability to add any picture making it extremely customisable. Worked fantastic (I use an iPhone so unsure about other OS)  Waiting time wasn’t as fast as mentioned though. Came here at 10+ am on a Tuesday and waited roughly 40mins
Very nice, small museum. Not crowded at all. There are a lot of benches. I can recommend to every Monet's fan

I found this beautiful museum by chance on the map and did not know it hosts the largest exposition of Monet paintings. It was such a beautiful experience being so close up to the paintings, seeing the brush strokes and thickness of the oil paint on the canvases.  I absolutely loved the Orangerie for its scale, but this is a close second. The fact that the museum is not as busy, and that you have time and space to sit with the paintings in some quiet moments is simply marvellous.  A little gem of a museum and the parks in the surroundings are very inviting on a sunny day - would totally recommend to walk there and enjoy the way as well.

I was most excited about this museum amongst others in Paris - but found myself disappointed.  The concept of a museum housed in a chateau is designed to create a memorable visit. Monet’s Nympheas were the main attraction and were thoroughly enjoyable. Other works by Morisot, Gauguin, and others were also delightful.  However, its narrow and confusing layout made it an unpleasant viewing experience, especially with so many visitors inside. For some reason, it was by far the noisiest museum I had visited. Moreover, the absence of the famous Impression Sunrise made the visit less memorable and left me wanting.

The world’s biggest collection of works by Claude Monet. The home of Paul Marmottan had grown and was now also the home of the father of Impressionism. The museum became known as the Musée Marmottan Monet.The home of Paul Marmottan had grown and was now also the home of the father of Impressionism. The museum became known as the Musée Marmottan Monet.
Great permanent display of Monet s paintings. They is always a great  expo at this place. The last one was ‘ le trompe l’œil’

We started our day with Musee Marmottan Monet. No regrets at all. My wife is more into arts. I found the art on the 2nd floor interesting.  Spend probably 20 minutes to staring on it somehow.  Btw all Monet Arts on the basement level.

One of the premier art museums in Paris, this place showcases a diverse collection of art pieces spanning various eras and styles.  What's particularly impressive is the compatible app available, allowing you to scan paintings for additional information, including both their contents and the stories behind them.  It's a must-visit for art lovers, as you could easily spend at least an hour exploring the various masterpieces on display.

Very interesting museum that avoids the crowds. Based around Monet with some Renoir and Degas, and Berthe Morisot. Also includes occasional exhibitions of other artists, and focuses on the art of the Trompe L'Oeuil over 500 years. Based in a former hunting lodge, the house itself is interesting. A great visit and good value.
Museum collection is ok compared to musee d’Orsay.  In any other city it’d be the most important museum. See if you have time
Exceptional museum! Great Picasso paintings. Love his range.

A museum that houses the most of Monet’s work in the world is thankfully smaller than expected, quiet and not overwhelmed by other tourists. It’s wonderful to stare at and observe the separate abstracted elements of the paintings. Some interesting objects and paintings upstairs as well. Highly recommend!  The surrounding neighborhood was probably my favorite in Paris. Quiet and beautiful.

Thanks to the recommendation of a friend I visited this quiet and inauspicious museum which nonetheless houses the world’s largest assemblage of the works of Monet, along with a small number of the works of other impressionist friends of Monet. The relative obscurity of this museum, located a bit away from the trendy tourist districts, results in a much quieter experience than visits to some of the more widely touted museums. Here I was able to enjoy in peace and quiet a number of Monet’s finest paintings without being overwhelmed by the scale of a massive collection of art spread over thousands of feet of floor space.  If you like to bask in the work of an artist and be able to quietly contemplate and study each of your favorite paintings, and if you love Monet’s work, it would be hard to top a visit to this lovely private museum.
It’s quiet crowded. Maybe it’s because we were visiting at the weekend. But Monet’s collection was worth to visit. If you like the impressionist.
What an outstanding experience to stand in front of these incredible paintings. Monet's son had his father's collection (not all) and created this beautiful place. A must see when in Paris.

It’s definitely a hidden gem and treasure museum! It’s really rare and underrated museum doesn’t like the other in the 1st arrondissement area. But totally worth the visit. You can see the beautiful artworks paintings of Claude Monet and also his son Michael Monet, and not another great artists like Berthe Morisot and family.

A Parisian hidden gem and a must-visit for Monet fans. This intimate museum showcases the evolution of Monet's artistry, with vibrant paintings and personal belongings that offer a deep connection to the artist.  The curated displays and insightful information make for a captivating journey through Monet's life. For art enthusiasts, this museum is an extraordinary experience that shouldn't be missed.  I have discovered this with my wife last week and we fell in love with the place.  I highly recommend.

This is a hidden gem of a museum! The Monets are wonderful and I was never in a room with more than 4 people.  Bonus room of Berthe Morisot paintings, decorative arts, and temporary exhibition on game/sport themed work for the Olympics. I didn’t try the garden cafe.

The queue outside is handled terribly. There are 3 queues, one for those without tickets, one for those with tickets and one for groups. I prebooked for 2pm, asked a security guard where to go when I arrived at 1:55pm and he sent be to the back of the queue for people with tickets. He was letting all groups in immediately (pretty sure people pretended to be groups to get in faster) and even after being in the queue until 2:30pm stood in the pouring rain he barely let anyone with tickets in. Ridiculous experience so definitely not worth booking tickets.  Inside was ok, the only saving grace about the place was the extensive Monet paintings they have which are displayed in the basement. The rest of the exhibits were average.

Great to see some of Monet's work which is located in the basement, through the gift shop. Had to ask.  Not very busy either since it is off the beaten path.  They provide free lockers to store your bags and purses.

Cool museum. I'm not entirely convinced it's worth the price of admission or has as many monet art pieces as I expected but it was a good museum to explore and spend a few hours. They have a cafe and sculptures too. We went solely expecting a super large collection of monet. They had a lot in his water lillies series and much of the art had to be appreciated far away as well as close by

Great museum with exposition not only of Monet works. The exposition is on 3 floors, also there is an app Myse that helps to explore more about paintings, sculptures etc. Not overcrowded as other museums therefore you can enjoy art not stressing about crowds around.
Absolute must if you enjoy Monet. Great collection and beautiful building.

This was easy access taking bus #32 from the Trocadero, the bus stop is across the street. This was an excellent jewel if you want something quiet instead of the likes of the Louvre or D'Orsay. The total number of Monet paintings in this collection is very large thanks to the generosity of one of Claude Monet's last surviving relatives. You can easily spend two (2) hours looking around. This a highly recommended stop.
A must-see for Impressionism's lovers. It also has a room of Nympheas, but the place is much quieter than the Musée de l'Orangerie.

Honestly, the best exhibition of Monet's works that I've seen in any permanent or travelling exhibition. There is time and space to enjoy the works, get real close and then benches to sit and admire and get lost in the beauty that is Impressionism.  The other exhibits are also well worth it and  beautifully restored and modelled rooms with period pieces.  Definitely worth it and a better experience than some of the bigger, busier galleries and museums

Very long wait outside in the pouring rain. This because there is a person to pack the visitors umbrellas. Then Another person to check the visitors body and bags as at an airport, before entering. These people are rude and do not speak English. Then confusing situations occur. As a visitor I don't understand why I am pushed to a side and yelled at when I thought I already entered the museum. It was time for the arms up and full body scan. After this whole scene without even entering I left, I prefer watching monets art from a book. Or not at all. Do not bother except you want to lose your time.and money and be badly treated.
A little bit off the beaten path, but definitely worth the visit. A smaller, more personal museum experience. They have some lovely Monet paintings as well as a changing exhibit schedule.

Loved my visit here, a much quieter museum. And a must do for Paris as it houses the leading collection of works from the worlds first female impressionist. Berthe Morisot. The house and architecture of the museum are fantastic. It sprawls on and on.  My critique —>  the artist mainly advertised is Monet when this Museum houses the worlds leading collection on Berthe Morisot, the worlds first female impressionist and theres hardly a mention of it anywhere until you get inside the museum.  Please note that as this is a private museum is doesn’t matter if you qualify for free entrance. You will need to buy a ticket.

This is a wonderful place to see Monet's up close. Rarely crowded so you can enjoy the pieces intimately. And don't miss the Morisot paintings upstairs, plus Napoleon's desk and bed. A wonderful place and I've been there a couple times now.
I really enjoyed the experience at the museum. The staff were very friendly. A must-see if you are a fan of Monet and Morisot.
